audit_revision: CORRECTED - Using HELIO_RV and proper M-dwarf SNR assessment

task1_lamost_rv_version_control.reason: 20.1 km/s RV change at 4.5 sigma significance confirms genuine variability. Two independent LAMOST epochs with consistent coordinates and spectral classification.

contamination_analysis.conclusion: 13% flux contamination cannot explain 146 km/s DESI amplitude. Even if companion had RV offset of 100 km/s, would only shift measured RV by ~13 km/s.

task2_blend_contamination.reason: While companion exists at 0.688 arcsec, the 13% flux contamination is insufficient to explain the observed 146 km/s RV amplitude. The elevated RUWE may reflect the genuine astrometric wobble from a massive dark companion.

task3_spectrum_reliability.reason: SNR_i values of 35.7 and 27.0 are adequate for M-dwarf RV measurement. M-dwarfs have strongest RV features (TiO bands) in the red/infrared where SNR is high. Low g-band SNR is expected and irrelevant for this spectral type.

key_evidence.blend_contamination_impact: Too small (13%) to explain observed amplitude

recommendation: RETAIN on high-priority follow-up list. The forensic audit confirms genuine RV variability at high significance. The candidate remains a strong dark companion candidate requiring spectroscopic follow-up to constrain orbital parameters.
